It is a film about having faith and how to accept every day like it is new and amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.sentences: I am glad that you put, GG -- "Getting Grace" right on the floor.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are one of Hollywood's busiest character actors. Were you ever a leading man in anything?

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.sentences: Well, in "Getting Grace" but you know, I had to write and direct and produce it, co-write it, wrote it with Jeff Lewis. I had to do all that to cast myself in this role, but I have been a leading man like in "Cave Girl," you may not remember.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I remember "Cave Girl."

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.sentences: "Cave Girl" I was the leading man and then in "River's Edge" I guess, I was a leading man, but then I killed the leading lady.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true. If you have not seen "River's Edge," again, a terrific film. You don't get any money out of that now though?

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.sentences: A little bit, a little bit. But let's talk about "Getting Grace." So, "Getting Grace" is opening nationwide and we made it in -- you and I share an amazing thing, we lived in the same place for a little while.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Allentown, Pennsylvania. Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.sentences: We shot the movie there in the Lehigh Valley.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, a beautiful, beautiful area and a wonderful location and they supported you, that's was the support.

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.sentences: It was so great. We are coming back to do another one. We are going to do a movie called, "The Hail Mary." But "Getting Grace" is -- one of the characters is the town and to make a movie in the place you grew up and go, "There's my hotdog shop, and that's the place I used to kiss the girl." Where we have the Yoccos, pizza. I have got to be fair, spread the love, and they are all in the movie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Excellent. You got a lot of free Yocco's hotdogs. All right.

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.sentences: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dan, we've got to go. Thank you, Dr. Jordan Peterson. Daniel Roebuck, Kat Timpf, Tyrus. Our studio audience. I am Greg Gutfeld, I love you, America. Believe me, if he weren't getting lower unemployment or tax cut bonuses and talks with North Korea, Trump the personality would not be half as popular. The fact is, everyone has a talent. A skunk has one. A peacock has one, but a skunk cannot impersonate a peacock or vice versa. So, Joe, stick to what you know like hugs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Here we go. Look at that. It goes on a little too long. Yes, yes, there it is. He is feeling uncomfortable. Yes. All right, enough.

He's got an explosive new film out called, "Getting Grace". She is no waitress, but she brings a lot to the table. National Review reporter, Kat Timpf. And he can't play hide and seek, Impact wrestler and my massive sidekick, Tyrus. Dr. Peterson you are a psychologist, a renowned psychologist. utterances.speaker: JORDAN PETERSON, UNIVERSITY OF TORONTO PSYCHOLOGY PROFESSOR
utterances.utterance: Split personality obviously.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, definitely. Yes, tribal?

utterances.speaker: PETERSON
utterances.utterance: Increasingly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PETERSON
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think that might be driven by the failure of the standard media at least to some degree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You mean, CNN?

utterances.speaker: PETERSON
utterances.utterance: Yes, sure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You only do Fox News, do you?

utterances.speaker: PETERSON
utterances.utterance: No, Fox News, yes, well, I think that as readership and viewership shrinks, it's easier to use click bait and to use tactics of indignation to attract decreasing viewership and that that might be driving the polarization to some degree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PETERSON
utterances.utterance: It's partly a technological transformation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it seems like in terms of polarization, people are seeking order out of chaos, right? They like to hear the things that they want to hear and that is just -- isn't that how we all are? We just like to be around people that are like us?

utterances.speaker: PETERSON
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, we -- in the past, we have been able to maintain a reasonably civil dialogue. Look, I haven't seen things this polarized. utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The identity politics that is now putting the group before the individual.

utterances.speaker: PETERSON
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's a terrible thing to do that and it is an invitation to tribalism and tribalism is an invitation to conflict, so you think the great -- one of the great achievements of the West as far as I am concerned is that we figured out a long time ago, and maybe several thousand years ago that that individual should always be subordinate to the state. That's the great discovery of western civilization.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, Professor Dan.

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.utterance: Yes, doctor -- I was a doctor in "Lost" -- Dr. Artz.

utterances.utterance: You were a doctor in "Lost."

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.utterance: I was. I was nowhere near as smart as Dr. Preston Jordan though, but I am intrigued by this whole idea that -- I mean, we love sports and that is tribalism, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.utterance: We're all into that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.utterance: So, we've done that and I always thought that maybe was the thing that we put instead of like fighting. We all had sports, am I am wrong? I don't know, I just came with that. I was trying to act smart. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you know, Kat, you sometimes feel alone, but you don't do anything really bad.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Not to brag, no, I don't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes. It's a very low bar.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

We live in a free society unfortunately. We also live in a society where we -- everyone has become a star. Everyone is -- if you look at -- look at social media, even the most -- everyone has got a selfie. Everyone is the most important person in their own world, and then the reality is, you are not. And there are no coping skills that I see for the people that really suffer on those things, where they don't -- you are not a star. You are not as cool as you think that you might be and some people take that -- and when you have a deviant personality and you have issues, and you have things like that, you struggle within and then the reality is, you have to face that and there is no outlet because everyone -- you are not allowed to label anybody. You don't have to say, "Well that guy is off," or he is different. You know, he's special. Everyone is -- he is a volunteer. Like you can't say that he's (inaudible) crazy. We have got to do something with him. You can't say that because I am judging. We're not very honest anymore.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The top line.

utterances.speaker: ROEBUCK
utterances.utterance: Can I just like -- what if we just stop saying the names of the terrible people? No, really, like, why do we put the names like you do it-- nobody says your name again. You're gone. You'll never get anything for it. I don't understand.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: (Inaudible) man, criminal, murderer. We have domestic terrorists.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: ROBERT GRAY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Live from America's News Headquarters, I am Robert Gray. An emotional day in the nation's capital and around the world as massive crowds rallying against gun violence. In one of the most powerful speeches of the day, Parkland shooting survivor, Emma Gonzalez stood silent for six minutes and 20 seconds. That is the amount of time she said it took for a gunman to kill 17 people and wounded 15 others on Valentine's Day at Margery Stoneman Douglas High School. Many in the crowd shed tears as Gonzalez stood in silence. There are also smaller counter protests across the nation in support of the Second Amendment. In Utah, pro-gun advocates shouted "freedom" as they marched on the state capital in Salt Lake City. Now, back to "The Greg Gutfeld Show."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, Facebook, more like in your face, book. That makes me laugh. Facebook's CEO, Mark Zuckerberg is doing damage control after millions had their info taken from his website without consent. Meanwhile, perhaps out of fear of media vengeance, Facebook changed its algorithms suppressing conservative views, sources and news on its site. As a result, conservative websites have seen large drops in traffic. The liberal sites, not so much. This week, a campaign to delete Facebook accounts started gaining popularity. It seems that the market is right for a new social network, so I made one. Here is the first ad for it.
